ygData.subject: Learning How to Learn
ygData.msgSnippet: A 44-neuron ANN has evolved which is a perfect player of the 4-card puzzle. To recapitulate if you have not been following this, there is deck of 4 cards, 2

Subject: Learning How to Learn
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=104426122
X-Yahoo-Profile: zenguyuno

A 44-neuron ANN has evolved which is a perfect player
of the 4-card puzzle.

To recapitulate if you have not been following this,
there is deck of 4 cards, 2 aces and 2 deuces.  The
deck is shuffled and placed face down.  This is shown
to the ANN.  Then one card is picked at random &
exposed; This is shown to the ANN.  Then another card
is picked, at random except so as NOT to form a pair
with the first card.  This is shown to the ANN.  Then
the card are turned face down again and this is shown
to the ANN.  The ANN now picks a card; this is exposed
and show to the ANN.  It picks a second card.  If it
has picked a pair it wins, otherwise it loses.  If it
makes an illegal or undefined pick it loses.

I think its clear that the ANN must remember what it
has seen and act correctly upon that information.  Its
first pick is always one of the card that has not been
exposed.  Its second pick is the matching one from the
cards that have been exposed.  Hence it needs to
remember which cards were exposed and what their
values were.

Furthermore, this memory is not stored in the weights,
since this ANN has its weights fixed.  The memory is
in the state of the ANN, which is a fully recurrent,
fully connected, binary ANN.  The state consists of
the outputs of all of the neurons.  What is stored in
the weights is the strategy of how to use the state as
a memory and how to make use of that information.

A friend of mine, Prof. Roderick Edwards here at U.
Vic., pointed out that the evolution software "learned
how to learn".  This seems apt to me.  The program had
to kill off a few millions ANNs that wouldn't quite
play perfectly until finally producing some that
could.  That was the machine learning phase, and the
results are fixed in the weights of the ANN.  Now the
ANN can learn what it need to when it plays this game.

I'm interested in finding out if this has been done
before; i.e., has someone trained a recurrent ANN so
that it makes use of its memory while doing its job. 
I suspect some of your robots with NEAT ANN
controllers qualify under this definition.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
